if $A \in \mathbb{R}^{n\times n}$ is diagonalizable (that is, it has $n$ eigenvectors that are linearly independent $v_1,\dots,v_n$, corresponding $\lambda_i$) and $Y = AY'$
$\implies$ $Y(t) = \matrixstart v_1 \cdots v_n \matrixend \matrixstart e^{\lambda_1t} & \cdots & 0 \\ 0 & \ddots & 0 \\ 0 & \cdots & e^{\lambda_n t}\matrixend {\matrixstart v_1 \cdots v_n \matrixend}^{-1} Y_0$


For a case like
\begin{align}
    v_1 &= u+iv \\
    v_2 &= u-iv \\
    v_3 &= v_3
\end{align}

We would have $Y(t) = \matrixstart u & v & v_3 \matrixend \matrixstart e^{at}\cos(bt) & e^{at}\sin(bt) & 0 \\ -e^{at}\sin(bt) & e^{at}\cos(bt) & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & e^{\lambda_3} \matrixend {\matrixstart u & v & v_3 \matrixend}^{-1}Y_0$
